title: How to Choose Radishes

steps.headline: Select small to medium-sized radishes for the best taste.
steps.description: For the commonly chosen red globe radish, pick ones that are about the size of a ping pong ball. Smaller is better when it comes to choosing radishes. Varieties like white daikon grow larger, but choose ones that are in the middle size range for each type. Larger radishes are not necessarily worse, but small to medium-sized radishes tend to have a better taste to them.

steps.headline: Check for crisp, green leaves.
steps.description: If you buy a bunch of radishes with their leaves intact, the leaves should look stiff and be bright green. Wilted or brown leaves are a sure sign that the radish is past its prime. It will not be crispy or taste good if the leaves look bad. If the radishes have already had their tops removed, pay close attention to the other factors.

steps.headline: Look for the most vibrant color.
steps.description: The color of a radish is a strong indicator of its taste. If you are looking for red radishes, pick the ones that are a rich, full red. Select white radishes that are bright white, almost translucent. Avoid dull or dark radishes.

steps.headline: Check bagged radishes for mold.
steps.description: Some radishes are sold in a bunch in a plastic bag. Always open the bag and pull the radishes apart to make sure no mold has grown in the bag. Radishes are often kept moist, which is good for freshness but also gives mold a place to grow.

steps.headline: Rub your fingers on the skin of the radish.
steps.description: Grab radishes with unblemished skin, and avoid ones with cracked, wrinkled, or knobby skin. Run your hand across the skin to see if it is smooth. Only buy radishes whose skin is smooth.

steps.headline: Gauge the heaviness of the radish.
steps.description: You want a radish that is full of juice, which makes it heavier. When you pick up a radish, see if it feels heavy for its size. This heaviness means its root is dense and healthy. If it feels light, don’t get it. You aren’t looking for a specific weight, so you have to make a judgment. Think of the difference between a ping pong ball and a golf ball.

steps.headline: Squeeze the radish to judge its firmness.
steps.description: A firm radish is a healthy, quality radish. Give it a gentle squeeze and see if it gives at all. If it feels firm, it’s a good one. If it feels spongy, it’s not a good radish and you should not buy it. If the radish feels firm, the inside is crunchy, which is what you want.

steps.headline: Check the very bottom of the root for its stiffness.
steps.description: The end of the root gives you a good idea of the quality of the radish. Wilted root ends are a sign the radish is past its prime. Grab the protruding finger at the end of the root and see if it feels stiff and firm. Don't buy a radish if the end of the root feels squishy and wilted.

steps.headline: Cut the tops off to preserve freshness.
steps.description: If you leave the tops on the radishes, they will go bad more quickly. Cut the leaves completely off. It doesn’t hurt to even cut just a bit of the top of the radish off to be safe. Dispose of these in a compost bin, toss them out on your lawn, or throw them in the garbage. Radish tops can be eaten, as well. Just make sure to eat them within a few days because they won’t stay good as long as the roots do.

steps.headline: Place them in an open plastic bag.
steps.description: Some store-bought radishes are already bagged, so leave them in the bag. If you buy them unbagged, grab a plastic produce bag at the grocery store. Keep the radishes in the bag, slightly wrapped up but not airtight.

steps.headline: Keep them refrigerated.
steps.description: For the best results, store your fresh radishes in the refrigerator. They might last a few days if you leave them out, but this is not usually a good idea. Store them in the crisper drawer to help them maintain moisture.

steps.headline: Eat radishes within ten days to two weeks.
steps.description: Check on stored radishes every couple of days to make sure they are still in good condition. It’s up to you to make sure they seem good to eat, because their shelf life varies from four or five days to two weeks. Use the tests for choosing radishes to make sure they are still good while you’re storing them.
